Multiple medical problems as listed above
Generalized edema and anasarca with right lower extremity painful erythematous lesion on the right shin which does not look like cellulitis on clinical exam
Area is markedly tender and is cool to touch. There is no signs of abscess lymphangitis
I doubt this is cellulitis but no objection to empiric antibiotics for 48 hours to see if it responds
MRI of the right leg is indicated however patient has hardware which may not be compatible
May do a CT scan if he does not improve and consider biopsy
improvement noted in the right leg, not sure if this is from antibiotics or fluid removal
Discussed with cardiology, patient has received about 10 days of outpatient doxycycline followed by inpatient vancomycin and Zosyn for 5 days.
To give him benefit of doubt we will recommend to give him another 7 days of oral Augmentin 500 mg daily and reassess him as outpatient
If symptoms relapse may consider dermatology consultation , CT scan of the leg and/or biopsy of the skin
Tariq mehmood, MD FIDSA

Mr Parker is a 51 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), s/p HM3 as DT on 2021-10-24, CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA, CKD stage 4, HD MWF.
Presents to PLVAD clinic for follow up after recent hospital d/c.
Pt was admitted 2 weeks ago for Syncope/AMS /lethargy, likely d/t hypoglycemia, BS 30 with EMS, mentation improved with improved blood sugar, A/O x 3.
At that time, he c/o R LE pain, redness and swelling, received IV vanco which is transitioned to Doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days for RLE cellulitis.
He endorses compliance with medications, however, he reports worsening pain/redness and swelling on RLE. He denies fever, chills. WBC WNL. Reports excruciating pain RLE for which he has taken some Lortab 10 mg since yesterday that he bought from his friend. He states he bought only 10 of them and it was not helping with pain. His UDS + for opiates and tricyclic antidepressant. On examination, RLE has 2+ edema, erythematous, tender to touch, warm and weeping serous fluid with some opened area.
He reports compliance with HD schedule, last HD yesterday. He reports significant bil Le edema, abdominal tightness. Denies CP/SOB/palpitation, dizziness, n/v/d,fever, chills, bright red bleeding per rectum, hematochezia, melena.
Denies LVAD alarms and ICD shocks.
DLES noted to have moderate amount of serous drainage.
Concerning blood sugars, he has not seen PCP yet, has been taking Lantus 48 units and humalog 7 units tid instead of 20 units Lantus and 3 unit Humalog tid that was prescribed and discussed at d/c. He states he has been checking blood sugars intermittently and thinks it was between 150-250.
He is being admitted under HF service for further management of worsening RLE cellulitis that requires IV abx (failed oral abx) and ongoing volume overload issue in the setting of LVAD and HD MWF.

Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis, severe RLE pain, failed oral abx and ongoing volume overload issue in the setting of LVAD and HD MWF.
afebrile, WBC WNL, recently completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days, now worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing. Started empiric IV abx-Vanc and Zosyn, completed 5 days. RLE cellulitis improvement noted with IV Abx and daily HD for removal of fluid, not sure if this is from antibiotics or fluid removal. ID recommends to continue Abx with oral Augmentin 500 mg daily for 5 more days.
Vascular consulted, pt declined ABI and US duplex d/t pain in LE. He aggress to complete them as out patient. For pain control, norco seems helping, on weaning process, prescribed 2 more days worth of Norco 10 q8H PRN for pain.
Concerning volume overload, followed by nephrology, volume improved with daily dialysis now switched to MWF. Pt to have HD tomorow as outpt, arrangements made.
LVAD stable, BP at goal.
During the course of his stay, the following issues were addressed:
# RLE cellulitis
afebrile, WBC WNL
completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days
-worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing
-Started empiric IV abx-Vanc and Zosyn, completed 5 days.
-RLE cellulitis improvement noted with IV Abx and daily HD for removal of fluid, not sure if this is from antibiotics or fluid removal.
- ID recommends to continue Abx with oral Augmentin 500 mg daily for 5 more days.
-Vascular consulted, pt declined ABI and US duplex d/t pain in LE. He aggress to complete them as out patient.
- pain control, norco seems helping, on weaning process, prescribed 2 more days worth of Norco 10 q8H PRN for pain.
#Acute on Chronic HFrEF
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24

--HD M W fr
- nephrology following
# Uncontrolled DM type 2
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04 and 5.6 on 3/30
- Recently reduced Lantus to 20 units daily and lispro 3 units AC tid + SSi d/t hypoglycemia, however, pt has been taking Lantus 48 units and lispro 7 units tid ac+ SSI despite of multiple discussions on decreased dose at last discharge
-monitor BS closely, cont lantus 20 units and lispro 3 tid+SSI
# Hx Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Hx substance abuse
-hx smoking marijuana for several years, now states quit since VAD implant
-2022-02-03 UDS + for opiates and tricyclic antidepressant, no opiates were prescribed for pt
-Reports excruciating pain RLE for which he has taken some Lortab 10 mg that he bought from his friend.
- started on Lortab for short period of time for pain and cellulitis of RLE, weaning off , given prescription for 2 more days q8h norco 10, no further refills
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.

Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis, severe RLE pain, failed oral abx and ongoing volume overload issue in the setting of LVAD and HD MWF.
afebrile, WBC WNL, recently completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days, now worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing. Started empiric IV abx-Vanc and Zosyn ID consult and further recommendations appreciated. Blood cultures NGTD. Vascular consulted to r/o PVD. Pt denied doppler studies, they signed off.
Regarding pain control: pt states Morphine does not help, asking for Dilaudid. Morphine d/c'd and started on Percocet 10 q 4h , weaned to Q6 today. Plan to wean off totally. Discussed that hopefully pain will get better once swelling comes down with HD and IV ABx in for next 48 hrs.
Concerning volume overload, nephrology following, plans noted for daily dialysis until his volume status returned to his dry weight. Received HD today, will return to MWF. LVAD stable, BP at goal.
Plan for DC tomorrow or next if ok with ID and nephro. Recs for abx transition appreciated. Continue outpatient HD MWF.

Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis, severe RLE pain, failed oral abx and ongoing volume overload issue in the setting of LVAD and HD MWF.
afebrile, WBC WNL, recently completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days, now worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing. Started empiric IV abx-Vanc and Zosyn pending ID consult and further recommendations. Blood cultures pending, consult vascular r/o PVD.
Regarding pain control: pt states Morphine does not help, asking for Dilaudid. Morphine d/c'd and started on Percocet 10 q 4h with plans to wean off. Discussed that hopefully pain will get better once swelling comes down with HD and IV ABx in for next 48 hrs.
Concerning volume overload, nephrology following, plans noted for daily dialysis until his volume status returned to his dry weight.
LVAD stable, BP at goal.
ATTESTATION:
Patient seen/evaluated and I agree with above. No issues overnight. VAD stable. RLE erythema improving (? abx vs fluid removal). Appreciate assistance from Nephrology and ID. VAD stable.

The patient, Michael Parker is 51-year-old white male, who has a history of nonischemic cardiomyopathy, status post LVAD placement, history of obesity, type 2 diabetes, dyslipidemia, history of CKD stage 4 with acute on chronic
renal failure resulting in ESRD. The patient always comes in, get hospitalize due to anasarca. The patient has very tight edema on lower extremities, going up to his thighs. He has no fever or leukocytosis and given right lower extremity redness and pain he was started on vancomycin and Zosyn empirically. ID was consulted for possible cellulitis. Patient was seen in the hemodialysis room. He complains of severe right leg pain and would not allow me to touch it. He does not have any fever or leukocytosis however. There is no edema on the left leg but no redness
No warmth open wound or induration noted on the right anterior leg. His blood cultures are negative
He denies any history of trauma
Patient also have history of hypertension, diabetes and congestive heart failure and is status post LVAD implantation.

This is a 51-year-old Caucasian male currently admitted to Jewish Hospital with fluid overload. He has a past medical history of CKD. We saw him last month when he was hospitalized. At that time he underwent right arm AV fistula creation and removal of his tunneled dialysis catheter as he was no longer requiring dialysis at the time. A few days later he went back into renal failure and required placement of another tunneled dialysis catheter. He now presents with fluid overload and right leg pain. This is a patient with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy. He has a HeartMate 3 ventricular assist device. He complains of excruciating pain in his right leg. He states that it is tender to the touch and will not allow me to look at it.

Mr Parker is a 51 year old male with PMHx of ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), s/p HM3 as DT on 2021-10-24, CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA, CKD stage 4, HD MWF.
# RLE cellulitis
afebrile, WBC WNL
completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days
-worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing
-Started empiric IV abx pending ID recommendation
- blood cultures on admission pending results
-consult vascular r/o PVD, appreciate recs
-pain control: pt states Morphine does not help, asking for Dilaudid. Morphine d/c'd and started on Percocet 10 q 4h with plans to wean off. Discussed that hopefully pain will get better once swelling comes down with HD and IV ABx in for next 48 hrs.
#Acute on Chronic HFrEF
-s/p insertion of HeartMate 3 left ventricular assist device, ligation of left atrial appendage 2021-10-24
ICM
ICD (St. Jude)
Stage D, NYHA Class III
LVAD interrogated: stable
Speed/LSL: 6000/5600
Flow: 5.1
Power: 4.8
PI: 4.1
PI events:6
Alarms: none in last 24 hours
Changes made: None
DLES Stage: 2
LDH: 123
HF/ VAD education provided
Volume: hyper
Diuretics: Bumex 4 mg po BID, HD MWF
BB: Coreg 18.75 mg po bid
Hydralazine 150 mg Q8H, Isosorbide dinitrate 30mg TID
AC: ASA, Eliquis
DLES: dressing changes daily with Medihoney.
# CAD
- s/p PCI to RCA 2014
- LHC 3-2019: LM/LAD/LCX patent arteries and patent prox RCA stent
- Cont ASA/Statin and BB
# Persistent Afib
- Amio PO 200 mg daily
- AC as above
#CKD, stage IV
--Cr baseline 2-2.5
--s/p TDC removal and Right arm brachiocephalic fistula with Vascular on 2022-01-10
--s/p insertion of tunneled catheter in the right internal jugular vein on 2022-01-14 with Vascular.
--HD M W fr
-will consult nephrology
# Uncontrolled DM type 2
- Hgb A1c 7.6 on 2021-09-04 and 5.6 on 3/30
- Recently reduced Lantus to 20 units daily and lispro 3 units AC tid + SSi d/t hypoglycemia, however, pt has been taking Lantus 48 units and lispro 7 units tid ac+ SSI despite of multiple discussions on decreased dose at last discharge
-monitor BS closely, resume lantus 20 units and lispro 3 tid+SSI
# Hx Post-operative respiratory failure
- Extubated 2021-11-07
- Reintubated 2021-11-08 for airway protection
- Trach per Thoracic 2021-11-09, exchanged to 6XLT 2021-11-19
- Trach removed 2021-12-03,
-stable, on room air
# Hx substance abuse
-hx smoking marijuana for several years, now states quit since VAD implant
-2022-02-03 UDS + for opiates and tricyclic antidepressant, no opiates were prescribed for pt
-Reports excruciating pain RLE for which he has taken some Lortab 10 mg that he bought from his friend.
-Now started on Lortab for short period of time for pain and cellulitis of RLE with plan to wean off
# Lymph adenopathy
Surveillance neck CT recommended in approximately 3 months to reevaluate left lower neck/supraclavicular adenopathy of uncertain
etiology.
A/P:
Admitted for worsening RLE cellulitis, severe RLE pain, failed oral abx and ongoing volume overload issue in the setting of LVAD and HD MWF.
afebrile, WBC WNL, recently completed doxy 100 mg po bid x 10 days, now worsening redness/warmth and swelling with open areas oozing. Started empiric IV abx-Vanc and Zosyn pending ID consult and further recommendations. Blood cultures pending, consult vascular r/o PVD.
Regarding pain control: pt states Morphine does not help, asking for Dilaudid. Morphine d/c'd and started on Percocet 10 q 4h with plans to wean off. Discussed that hopefully pain will get better once swelling comes down with HD and IV ABx in for next 48 hrs.
Concerning volume overload, nephrology following, plans noted for d aily dialysis until his volume status returned to his dry weight.
LVAD stable, BP at goal.
Patient seen and examined with attending Dr. Dunbar Matos. The above assessment/ plans were outlined after discussing with attending.
Shared decision making was utilized in constructing this documentation and determination of the assessment and plan.

item.paragraph: (CR Chest 1 Vw Portable) Reason For Exam: On admission, to verify pump placement

paragraph.content:
INDICATION: Verify pump placement.
TECHNIQUE: Frontal chest was obtained at 1929 hours.
COMPARISON: 2022-01-21 CXR.
FINDINGS:
The cardiomediastinal silhouette remains enlarged. Left ventricular assist device
and left-sided cardiac pacer remain along with evidence of prior sternotomy. Also
unchanged is a right jugular catheter extending to the lower superior vena cava.
There is improved aeration in the right lung when compared to the prior study with
some residual discoid atelectasis and mild elevation of the right hemidiaphragm
remaining.. No definite pleural effusion is visible.. There is no pneumothorax.
No acute osseous process.
IMPRESSION:
There is improvement at the right base with better distended of the diaphragm but
there is still a small residual discoid atelectasis. Cardiomegaly remains but no
definite edema or alveolar consolidation is appreciated..
Signed by Joseph Bender, MD

***** Final *****

Edema
Edema is when you have too much fluid in your body or under your skin. Edema may make your legs, feet, and ankles swell up. Swelling is also common in looser tissues, like around your eyes. This is a common condition. It gets more common as you get older. There are many possible causes of edema. Eating too much salt (sodium) and being on your feet or sitting for a long time can cause edema in your legs, feet, and ankles. Hot weather may make edema worse.
Edema is usually painless. Your skin may look swollen or shiny.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Keep the swollen body part raised (elevated) above the level of your heart when you are sitting or lying down.
• Do not sit still or stand for a long time.
• Do not wear tight clothes. Do not wear garters on your upper legs.
• Exercise your legs. This can help the swelling go down.
• Wear elastic bandages or support stockings as told by your doctor.
• Eat a low-salt (low-sodium) diet to reduce fluid as told by your doctor.
• Depending on the cause of your swelling, you may need to limit how much fluid you drink (fluid restriction).
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your doctor.
Contact a doctor if:
• Treatment is not working.
• You have heart, liver, or kidney disease and have symptoms of edema.
• You have sudden and unexplained weight gain.
Get help right away if:
• You have shortness of breath or chest pain.
• You cannot breathe when you lie down.
• You have pain, redness, or warmth in the swollen areas.
• You have heart, liver, or kidney disease and get edema all of a sudden.
• You have a fever and your symptoms get worse all of a sudden.
Summary
• Edema is when you have too much fluid in your body or under your skin.
• Edema may make your legs, feet, and ankles swell up. Swelling is also common in looser tissues, like around your eyes.
• Raise (elevate) the swollen body part above the level of your heart when you are sitting or lying down.
• Follow your doctor's instructions about diet and how much fluid you can drink (fluid restriction).
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2019-08-21 Document Reviewed: 2018-09-05
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

Heart Failure, Self Care
Heart failure is a serious condition. This sheet explains things you need to do to take care of yourself at home. To help you stay as healthy as possible, you may be asked to change your diet, take certain medicines, and make other changes in your life. Your doctor may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, call your doctor.
What are the risks?
Having heart failure makes it more likely for you to have some problems. These problems can get worse if you do not take good care of yourself. Problems may include:
• Blood clotting problems. This may cause a stroke.
• Damage to the kidneys, liver, or lungs.
• Abnormal heart rhythms.
Supplies needed:
• Scale for weighing yourself.
• Blood pressure monitor.
• Notebook.
• Medicines.
How to care for yourself when you have heart failure
Medicines
Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your doctor. Take your medicines every day.
• Do not stop taking your medicine unless your doctor tells you to do so.
• Do not skip any medicines.
• Get your prescriptions refilled before you run out of medicine. This is important.
Eating and drinking
• Eat heart-healthy foods. Talk with a diet specialist (dietitian) to create an eating plan.
• Choose foods that:
◦ Have no trans fat.
◦ Are low in saturated fat and cholesterol.
• Choose healthy foods, such as:
◦ Fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables.
◦ Fish.
◦ Low-fat (lean) meats.
◦ Legumes, such as beans, peas, and lentils.
◦ Fat-free or low-fat dairy products.
◦ Whole-grain foods.
◦ High-fiber foods.
• Limit salt (sodium) if told by your doctor. Ask your diet specialist to tell you which seasonings are healthy for your heart.
• Cook in healthy ways instead of frying. Healthy ways of cooking include roasting, grilling, broiling, baking, poaching, steaming, and stir-frying.
• Limit how much fluid you drink, if told by your doctor.
Alcohol use
• Do not drink alcohol if:
◦ Your doctor tells you not to drink.
◦ Your heart was damaged by alcohol, or you have very bad heart failure.
◦ You are pregnant, may be pregnant, or are planning to become pregnant.
• If you drink alcohol:
◦ Limit how much you use to:
▪ 0–1 drink a day for women.
▪ 0–2 drinks a day for men.
◦ Be aware of how much alcohol is in your drink. In the U.S., one drink equals one 12 oz bottle of beer (355 mL), one 5 oz glass of wine (148 mL), or one 1½ oz glass of hard liquor (44 mL).
Lifestyle
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. If you need help quitting, ask your doctor.
◦ Do not use nicotine gum or patches before talking to your doctor.
• Do not use illegal drugs.
• Lose weight if told by your doctor.
• Do physical activity if told by your doctor. Talk to your doctor before you begin an exercise if:
◦ You are an older adult.
◦ You have very bad heart failure.
• Learn to manage stress. If you need help, ask your doctor.
• Get rehab (rehabilitation) to help you stay independent and to help with your quality of life.
• Plan time to rest when you get tired.
Check weight and blood pressure
• Weigh yourself every day. This will help you to know if fluid is building up in your body.
◦ Weigh yourself every morning after you pee (urinate) and before you eat breakfast.
◦ Wear the same amount of clothing each time.
◦ Write down your daily weight. Give your record to your doctor.
• Check and write down your blood pressure as told by your doctor.
• Check your pulse as told by your doctor.
Dealing with very hot and very cold weather
• If it is very hot:
◦ Avoid activities that take a lot of energy.
◦ Use air conditioning or fans, or find a cooler place.
◦ Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
◦ Wear clothing that is loose-fitting, lightweight, and light-colored.
• If it is very cold:
◦ Avoid activities that take a lot of energy.
◦ Layer your clothes.
◦ Wear mittens or gloves, a hat, and a scarf when you go outside.
◦ Avoid alcohol.
Follow these instructions at home:
• Stay up to date with shots (vaccines). Get pneumococcal and flu (influenza) shots.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.
Contact a doctor if:
• You gain weight quickly.
• You have increasing shortness of breath.
• You cannot do your normal activities.
• You get tired easily.
• You cough a lot.
• You don't feel like eating or feel like you may vomit (nauseous).
• You become puffy (swell) in your hands, feet, ankles, or belly (abdomen).
• You cannot sleep well because it is hard to breathe.
• You feel like your heart is beating fast (palpitations).
• You get dizzy when you stand up.
Get help right away if:
• You have trouble breathing.
• You or someone else notices a change in your behavior, such as having trouble staying awake.
• You have chest pain or discomfort.
• You pass out (faint).
These symptoms may be an emergency. Do not wait to see if the symptoms will go away. Get medical help right away. Call your local emergency services (911 in the U.S.). Do not drive yourself to the hospital.
Summary
• Heart failure is a serious condition. To care for yourself, you may have to change your diet, take medicines, and make other lifestyle changes.
• Take your medicines every day. Do not stop taking them unless your doctor tells you to do so.
• Eat heart-healthy foods, such as fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables, fish, lean meats, legumes, fat-free or low-fat dairy products, and whole-grain or high-fiber foods.
• Ask your doctor if you can drink alcohol. You may have to stop alcohol use if you have very bad heart failure.
• Contact your doctor if you gain weight quickly or feel that your heart is beating too fast. Get help right away if you pass out, or have chest pain or trouble breathing.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-11-30 Document Reviewed: 2020-12-01
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.
